page.title: 06Street Market in Cockermouth
page.content: There has been a Monday Market for 700 years. Cockermouth received a Market Charter in the reign of Henry III about 1222 A.D. About 1679 a regulation was introduced to make the buying and selling of goods fair to all. A scavenger had the duty to signal the opening of the market by ringing the bell at eleven o'clock. Then goods, especially butter could be sold. The bell hung in a niche, on the wall of the former Greyhound Inn and is there to-day on the south side of Market Place. One of our senior citizens retains the tradition and rings the Market Bell at 10 a.m. Business begins for the 15 stall-holders which includes goods such as fish, fruit and veg., cheese, clothes, hard-ware and a very popular plants and shrubs stall where you can buy "Old World" roses .
